problem: An object of mass 0.2 kg executes SHM along the X-axis with frequency 25/π Hz. At x = 0.04 m, the object has kinetic energy 0.5 J and potential energy 0.4 J. Find the amplitude of oscillations.

scenes.title: Setup — Problem Introduction

narration_segments.text: An object of mass zero point two kilograms executes simple harmonic motion along the x axis with frequency twenty five by pi hertz.

visual_actions: Show a simple mass-spring oscillator moving along x-axis with equilibrium marked.
Label given quantities: m equals 0.2 kg and f equals 25 by pi hertz.

scenes.title: Given Conditions and Objective

narration_segments.text: At position x equals zero point zero four meters, the kinetic energy is zero point five joules and potential energy is zero point four joules. We have to find the amplitude.

visual_actions: Show text: x = 0.04 m, KE = 0.5 J, PE = 0.4 J.
Highlight total energy equals KE plus PE.

scenes.title: Step 1 — Total Energy Relation

narration_segments.text: The total energy in simple harmonic motion is equal to one half k A squared.
At any position, potential energy is half k x squared.

visual_actions: Display MathTex: E = KE + PE = 1/2 k A^2.

narration_segments.text: Angular frequency omega equals two pi f. Substituting f equals twenty five by pi gives omega equals fifty radians per second.
Hence k equals m omega squared, equal to zero point two times fifty squared, equal to five hundred newtons per meter.
The total energy equals zero point nine joules. Substituting in E equals one half k A squared gives amplitude equals zero point zero six meters.

scenes.title: Final Summary

narration_segments.text: Therefore the amplitude of oscillation is zero point zero six meters.

visual_actions: Display final answer text in large yellow font: Amplitude A = 0.06 m.
Keep the oscillator moving for a short concluding animation.

final_notes.explanation_summary: By using energy relations and k = m ω², we find amplitude A equals 0.06 meters.
